To select all files with a certain postfix, such as *.gz, across all subdirectories in a specified directory, you can use the `rsync` command as previously discussed. Here's the command again for clarity:

```bash
rsync -avP --include='*/' --include='*.gz' --exclude='*' root@tt:/source/ /dest
```

This command will recursively search through the `/source/` directory and its subdirectories, including only files with the `.gz` postfix, and exclude other files. The `-a` flag preserves file attributes, `-v` provides verbose output, and `-P` enables progress reporting. 

The `--include='*/'` option ensures that directories are included, and `--include='*.gz'` specifies that only files with the `.gz` extension should be included. The `--exclude='*'` option excludes all other files and directories, ensuring that only the desired files are copied.

A: When rendering text in most HTML elements, browsers collapse multiple whitespace characters (spaces, tabs, newlines) into a single space by default. To preserve line breaks and display multi-line text, wrap the content in a <pre> tag.
